message: As everyone in the Old Residential District knows, the best way to get around is on foot.
Public transportation here is pretty bad. Technically, there are buses, trains, and even taxis available, but they can be cancelled or delayed without notice.

Even the roads themselves might be closed without notice, so you hardly see any cars around these days.

At most, you might see a taxi waiting in vain or the occasional junker parked on the side of the road.
The sidewalks, on the other hand, are always packed.
Nothing's more reliable than your own two legs.
The Old Residential District is divided into north, south, east, and west quarters. They're similar, but have some key differences.

For example, both my home and Hum-Drum Junk are located in the east quarter.

It's pretty safe compared to the other quarters, and it's easy to get your hands on whatever you need.
The north quarter's become something of a ghost town ever since it was designated off-limits. It's definitely not the safest place to go.
The west quarter is primarily residential, like the east quarter, but doesn't have as many stores.
The south quarter is an entertainment and shopping district, so it's always full of youngsters hanging out.
And if you go farther north, up past the north quarter, there's Platinum Jail, where the rich and famous do their business.
Platinum Jail is a members-only resort that the Toue Corporation, one of Japan's top five companies, built when they bought Midorijima.
If the rumors are true, that place is the definition of luxury.
Centered around the giant Oval Tower, it's full of casinos, movie theaters, shopping malls, hotels... everything you can imagine.
Membership is by invitation only, but even then, the membership fee alone costs more than this whole island is worth. Or so I've heard.
Obviously, no one from the Old Residential District will ever get into Platinum Jail.
So I guess you could call this town a slum. Nobody cares what happens here.
The police are all talk. They're in bed with the yakuza and just do whatever they please.
It's not like we can do anything about it. Even if we're unhappy, we just have to suck it up and deal with it.
Despite all that, as the saying goes: there really is no place like home. This town isn't so bad once you get used to it.
While it may not be as extravagant as Platinum Jail, we have our own way of life. Our own kinds of fun.
Can't really ask for much more than that.

name: 蓮
message: "Aoba... Aoba."
Ren pokes his head out of the bag and taps my arm with his paw.

name: 蒼葉
message: "What's the matter?"

name: 蓮
message: "You're thinking too much. Your logic processor will short-circuit."

name: 蒼葉
message: "Seriously? Just how crappy is this logic processor of mine anyway?"

name: 蓮
message: "If we rate the logic processor of an average male at 100, then yours would rate at―"

name: 蒼葉
message: "Wait! I don't wanna hear it. You'll make me short-circuit for real."

name: 蓮
message: "Oh."
I chuckle and pat his head.
Ren is a dog-type Allmate. Allmates are artificially intelligent lifeforms, generally used to augment network devices like Coils.
They can search the internet and virtual space for information, place orders for you in online stores, or manage your social media accounts.
Some models can also help around the house, while others can act as partners in an online game called Rhyme.
There are many different types of Allmate. Animal models are abundant, so many people keep them as pets.
I've had Ren for a long time. I'm not exaggerating when I say he's my best friend.
Even with all the improvements and new models coming out, I'll never abandon Ren. Not even if hell freezes over.

name: 蓮
message: "If you want to take a shortcut, turn right at the next street."

name: 蒼葉
message: "Woah, that was close. Almost missed it."
I follow Ren's directions down an alley off Aoyagi Street.

Aoyagi Street runs through the center of the Old Residential District, dividing the district into quarters.

It's lined with shops selling discount appliances, while the back streets are littered with niche hobby shops.
As I make my way down the alley, a group of guys leaning against a filthy wall catches my eye.

They have a certain look... like the kind of guys who'd be passing around a silver drug sheet.

It really makes you wonder what's wrong with kids these days.

Once upon a time, though, I was just like them.<k>
Uh, not that I'm old or anything.
Anyway, I'm finished with that stuff. Totally.
As I walk past, I catch a bit of their conversation.

name: 若者Ａ
message: "So yeah, it's really happening. People're getting brain-jacked."

name: 若者Ｂ
message: "What the hell're you talkin' about? Getting forced into Rhyme?"

name: 若者Ａ
message: "Yeah, that's exactly what I'm talkin' about! You'll just be walking down the street and a match'll start! Against a crazy strong opponent, too!"

name: 若者Ｂ
message: "But wouldn't that mean there's no Usui? Can you even play Rhyme without Usui?"

name: 若者Ａ
message: "Sounds like you can. I dunno how it works."

name: 若者Ｂ
message: "How can you fight if you're not ready? Can't you decline the challenge?"

name: 若者Ａ
message: "Not from what I hear. It's a total ganking―you get your ass handed to you like that."

name: 若者Ｂ
message: "That's some scary shit, man."
They're talking about Rhyme, the online fighting game that's all the rage these days.
By connecting their minds to the net, players can experience virtual combat that feels just like the real thing.

The thing is, there's no schedule or anything that tells you when or where a battle's gonna happen.

Wherever "Usui," the game's judge, appears―that's the battlefield.
Rhyme started off as an indie game. Back then, the rules were more lax, and Usui wasn't around either.
It steadily gained popularity, and eventually Toue became a major sponsor.
The system was improved and Usui was added, along with an official set of rules, making Rhyme what it is today.
But I don't play Rhyme, so it isn't really my business.
I head through the alley and come out once more on Aoyagi Street.
